title: Design dependency and relationship system for issues
description:
Design and implement a dependency/relationship system inspired by Beads issue tracker.

## Core Concepts from Beads

### 1. Dependencies (Blocking Relationships)
- Issue A **blocks** Issue B (B depends on A)
- `govtrack dep add <child> <parent>` - child depends on parent
- Blocked issues can't be worked until blockers are resolved
- `govtrack blocked` - show all blocked issues
- `govtrack ready` - show issues with no open blockers

### 2. Related Issues
- Softer relationship than dependencies
- "See also" connections between issues
- Useful for duplicates, similar reports, related work
- `govtrack relate <issue1> <issue2>`

### 3. Parent-Child Hierarchies (Epics)
- Issues can have sub-issues
- Hierarchical IDs: gi-a1b2.1, gi-a1b2.2
- Epic progress tracking (3/5 children closed)
- `govtrack epic create "Big Project"`
- `govtrack epic add-task <epic-id> <task-id>`

## Data Model Changes

Add to issue schema:
```json
{
  "depends_on": ["gi-xxxx", "gi-yyyy"],
  "blocks": ["gi-zzzz"],
  "related": ["gi-aaaa"],
  "parent_id": "gi-bbbb",
  "children": ["gi-cccc", "gi-dddd"]
}
```

## CLI Commands

| Command | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| `govtrack dep add <issue> <depends-on>` | Add dependency |
| `govtrack dep rm <issue> <depends-on>` | Remove dependency |
| `govtrack relate <issue1> <issue2>` | Link related issues |
| `govtrack unrelate <issue1> <issue2>` | Unlink issues |
| `govtrack blocked` | Show blocked issues |
| `govtrack ready` | Show unblocked issues |
| `govtrack show <id>` | Show deps in issue detail |

## Web UI Changes

- Issue detail page shows:
  - "Blocked by" section with linked issues
  - "Blocks" section  
  - "Related issues" section
- Visual dependency graph (nice to have)
- Filter by blocked/ready status
- Warning when closing issue that blocks others

## Other Beads Features to Consider

1. **Hash-based IDs** - Already implemented ✓
2. **JSONL storage** - Already implemented ✓
3. **History tracking** - Already implemented ✓
4. **Semantic compaction** - Summarize old closed issues to save space
5. **Sync/daemon** - Background sync with git
6. **Prime context** - Inject relevant context at session start
7. **Audit trail** - Track who changed what and when

## Implementation Phases

Phase 1: Dependencies (blocks/blocked-by)
Phase 2: Related issues
Phase 3: Parent-child hierarchies
Phase 4: Ready/blocked filtering in CLI and web

description:
## Overview
Implement live push notifications to keep logged-in users informed of relevant activity in real-time.

## Requirements

- **Real-time notifications via WebSocket or SSE**: Establish persistent connections for instant message delivery without polling
- **Notify users of new issues, updates, responses**: Alert users when issues they follow are created, modified, or receive new comments/responses
- **Desktop/browser notification support**: Integrate with the Web Notifications API to display system-level notifications even when the app is not in focus
- **In-app notification center/feed**: Provide a dedicated UI component where users can view, manage, and clear their notification history

title: Design: Separate Problems, Actions, and Human Needs layers
description:
Rethink the fundamental data model to distinguish between different types of civic concerns.

## The Insight

Currently we're mixing two (or more) distinct concepts:

1. **Actions/Tasks** - Concrete, actionable work items
   - "Fix pothole at 5th & Main"
   - "Replace broken streetlight"
   - "Process permit application #1234"
   - Has: assignee, due date, completion criteria

2. **Problems/Conditions** - Ongoing situations or systemic issues
   - "Homelessness in downtown area"
   - "Traffic congestion on I-35"
   - "Lack of affordable housing"
   - "Food deserts in East Austin"
   - Has: severity, affected population, trend (improving/worsening)

3. **Human Needs** (deeper layer) - Fundamental needs every citizen has
   - **Physical well-being**: shelter, food, healthcare, safety
   - **Connection**: community, belonging, relationships
   - **Autonomy**: freedom, choice, self-determination
   - **Integrity**: justice, fairness, respect, dignity
   - **Play**: recreation, creativity, rest
   - **Meaning**: purpose, contribution, growth

## The Hierarchy

```
Human Needs (foundational)
    ↑ addresses
Problems/Conditions (systemic)
    ↑ addresses  
Actions/Tasks (concrete)
```

Example chain:
```
Need: Physical well-being → Safety
  ↑
Problem: "High pedestrian accidents on South Congress"
  ↑
Actions: 
  - "Install crosswalk at South Congress & Oltorf"
  - "Add pedestrian crossing signals"
  - "Conduct traffic study"
```

## Why This Matters

1. **Actions without Problems are disconnected** - Why are we doing this?
2. **Problems without Needs are abstract** - What human impact does this have?
3. **Tracking only Actions misses the big picture** - We closed 100 tickets but did life improve?
4. **Citizens report Problems, not Actions** - "There's too much crime" not "Hire 5 officers"

## Proposed Data Model

### Layer 1: Needs (static taxonomy)
```json
{
  "id": "need-physical-safety",
  "category": "physical_wellbeing",
  "name": "Safety",
  "description": "Freedom from harm, violence, accidents"
}
```

### Layer 2: Problems
```json
{
  "id": "prob-a1b2",
  "title": "Pedestrian safety on South Congress",
  "type": "problem",
  "needs": ["need-physical-safety"],
  "severity": "high",
  "affected_population": "~50,000 residents",
  "trend": "worsening",
  "metrics": {
    "accidents_per_year": 47,
    "year": 2025
  },
  "gov_id": "gt-austin"
}
```

### Layer 3: Actions (current 'issues')
```json
{
  "id": "gi-x1y2",
  "title": "Install crosswalk at South Congress & Oltorf",
  "type": "action",
  "addresses": ["prob-a1b2"],
  "status": "open",
  "priority": 1,
  "gov_id": "gt-austin"
}
```

## Implementation Phases

### Phase 1: Two-layer model (Problems + Actions)
- Add `type` field: 'problem' | 'action' (default: 'action' for backward compat)
- Add `addresses` field to link actions → problems
- CLI: `govtrack problem "Pedestrian safety concern"`
- CLI: `govtrack action "Install crosswalk" --addresses prob-a1b2`
- Web: Separate views for Problems vs Actions

### Phase 2: Problem analytics
- Severity levels for problems
- Trend tracking (improving/stable/worsening)
- Affected population estimates
- Metrics over time

### Phase 3: Human Needs taxonomy
- Define canonical needs hierarchy (NVC-inspired or custom)
- Link problems to needs they affect
- Dashboard: "How are we doing on Safety? Housing? Connection?"
- Gap analysis: Which needs are underserved?

### Phase 4: Dependency graph visualization
- Full graph: Needs → Problems → Actions
- Impact analysis: "If we complete these actions, which problems improve?"
- Resource allocation: "Which needs are getting the most/least attention?"
- Citizen-facing: "Here's what we're doing about housing"

## Open Questions

1. Should Problems have status? (acknowledged, being addressed, resolved)
2. Can one Action address multiple Problems?
3. How do we measure if a Problem is actually improving?
4. Who defines the Needs taxonomy? (Marshall Rosenberg's NVC? Maslow? Custom?)
5. How do citizens report? Do they report Problems or Actions?

## References

- Nonviolent Communication (NVC) needs list
- Maslow's hierarchy of needs
- IDEO human-centered design
- Results-Based Accountability (RBA) framework

title: Urgent/Time-Sensitive Notification Escalation
description:
## Overview
Implement escalation rules for urgent and time-sensitive notifications in the GovTrack system.

## Requirements

### Escalation Rules for Urgent/Time-Sensitive Tags
- Notifications tagged as 'urgent' or 'time-sensitive' trigger immediate escalation workflow
- Define configurable escalation tiers (e.g., initial contact → supervisor → department head)
- Time-based escalation thresholds configurable per notification type

### Notification Types Based on Urgency
- **High Urgency (Immediate)**: SMS notification sent immediately
- **Medium Urgency**: Email notification with SMS fallback after threshold
- **Low Urgency**: Email notification only
- Support for push notifications as additional channel

### Escalation on No Response
- Track acknowledgment/response status for each notification
- If no response within configurable threshold (e.g., 15 min, 1 hour, 4 hours):
  - Escalate to next tier in escalation chain
  - Send reminder to original recipient
  - Log escalation event for audit trail

### Integration with Hazard Reporting Flow
- Connect to existing hazard reporting system
- Automatically apply urgency tags based on hazard severity
- Route hazard-related notifications through escalation pipeline
- Ensure compliance with safety reporting requirements

### Priority Levels Affecting Notification Urgency
- P1 (Critical): Immediate SMS + email, 15-minute escalation threshold
- P2 (High): SMS + email, 1-hour escalation threshold  
- P3 (Medium): Email with SMS after 2 hours, 4-hour escalation threshold
- P4 (Low): Email only, 24-hour escalation threshold
- Priority can be auto-assigned based on content analysis or manually overridden

title: Active Hazard Reporting & Urgent Issue Design
description:
## Overview
Design and implement a flow for reporting active hazards and urgent safety issues in real-time.

## Requirements

### Design flow for reporting active hazards
- Subway dangers (track obstructions, suspicious packages, medical emergencies)
- Street hazards (downed power lines, sinkholes, flooding)
- Building/infrastructure issues (structural damage, gas leaks)
- Public safety threats requiring immediate attention

### Time-sensitive issue tagging/classification
- Urgency levels: Critical (immediate danger), High (within hours), Medium (within day)
- Hazard type categories for quick filtering
- Auto-expiration for time-bound issues (e.g., icy conditions)
- Real-time status updates (reported → acknowledged → responding → resolved)

### Immediate escalation path for safety issues
- Direct routing to relevant city departments (311, emergency services)
- Automatic notification to nearby users in affected area
- Integration with official emergency response systems
- Fallback escalation if no response within threshold time

### Photo/video upload considerations
- Quick capture directly from app (camera integration)
- Support for existing media from gallery
- Automatic metadata extraction (timestamp, GPS coordinates)
- Media compression for fast upload on poor connections
- Privacy considerations for bystanders in media

### Location tagging
- Precise GPS coordinates with accuracy indicator
- Manual pin adjustment on map
- Landmark/address autocomplete
- Indoor location support (subway stations, buildings)
- Option to report hazard at different location than current position

### UX for quick hazard reporting in emergency situations
- One-tap hazard report button (accessible from any screen)
- Minimal required fields - expand details later
- Voice-to-text for hands-free reporting
- Offline mode with auto-sync when connection restored
- Large touch targets for stress/emergency situations
- Clear visual feedback and confirmation
- Estimated response time display

- 'Report Issue' button prominent
